content: I have a question about the names: should I keep them as they are or is it better to change fderiv_aux to fderiv and fderiv to fderiv_clm? To be honest I am not a huge fan of having the type in the variable name, but _aux is not really helpful either.
I think it's convention to include type in the name, e.g. docs#nat.cast, docs#nat.cast_add_monoid_hom, docs#nat.cast_ring_hom. (btw it's the declaration name not variable name right?)
It took me a while to notice the t in Schwartz in the title. I almost thought this was about Schwarzian derivatives. :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes: We don't have that, do we?
If it's any consolation, it took me over 30 years to discover that there was more than one Schwar(t)z in analysis and this discovery just happened now whilst reading this thread.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermann_Schwarz v https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurent_Schwartz

No wonder I never knew how to spell their name!
but you are aware that there was Carl Neumann (series and boundary conditions) and John von Neumann (almost everything else)?
my awareness of analysis is seriously limited :-)
One mnemonic trick is to conjecture that the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality was probably known a bit before the theory of distributions.
